truck0.goal: Assist in achieving the global crate placement goals while respecting load capacity and minimizing fuel-cost.

truck1.goal: Assist in achieving the global crate placement goals while respecting load capacity and minimizing fuel-cost.

hoist0.goal: Perform lifts/puts/loads/unloads at depot0 as needed to achieve global crate placement goals, ensuring single-lift discipline.

hoist1.goal: Perform lifts/puts/loads/unloads at distributor0 as needed to achieve global crate placement goals, ensuring single-lift discipline.

hoist2.goal: Perform lifts/puts/loads/unloads at distributor1 as needed to achieve global crate placement goals, ensuring single-lift discipline.

depot0.goal: Be the source/sink location for crates as required by the global rearrangement goal.

distributor0.goal: Host hoist and trucks to enable crate rearrangement for the global goals.

orchestrator.goal: Generate a PDDL domain and problem that encodes the multi-agent trucks-hoists-crates planning task, capturing objects, initial state including locations/stacks/weights/capacities/fuel-cost, action models for drive/lift/putdown/load/unload, capacity numeric constraint, and the goal configuration; objective is to minimize fuel-cost.

public_information: There are places: depot0 and distributors distributor0 and distributor1.
Trucks are mobile carriers between places and have numeric current_load and load_limit.
Hoists are located at places, can lift/putdown/load/unload crates, and have availability and lifting state.
Crates can be on surfaces (pallets or other crates) or inside trucks.
Surfaces may be clear or not clear; crates can be clear indicating nothing on top.
Fuel-cost is a global numeric accumulator increased by driving trucks (10) and operating hoists (1).
Objective is to minimize fuel-cost while achieving the target on-relations.

orchestrator.system_prompt: You are an expert with multi-agent PDDL problems. You will be provided information about the environment and the capabilities and knowledge of the agents which interact in the environment. You always provide a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem file that describes the planning problem. Enclose the pddl domain between <domain></domain> tags, and the pddl problem between <problem></problem> tags. Keep the actions for different agents distinct, so that there is no confusion as to which agent performs which action.
orchestrator.prompt:
Your name is orchestrator.
Initial information about the environment: {environment->init}.
Goal for the environment: {environment->goal}.
The public information is: {environment->public_information}.
The truck0's constraints are: {agents->agent_details->truck0->private_information}.
The truck1's constraints are: {agents->agent_details->truck1->private_information}.
The hoist0's constraints are: {agents->agent_details->hoist0->private_information}.
The hoist1's constraints are: {agents->agent_details->hoist1->private_information}.
The hoist2's constraints are: {agents->agent_details->hoist2->private_information}.
Think step by step and provide a PDDL domain and problem that encapsulate the integrated model, respecting the constraints of each agent. Model numeric fluents for truck loads, crate weights, and fuel-cost. Include actions: drive (truck moves between places, fuel-cost +10), hoist-lift (hoist lifts crate from surface, fuel-cost +1), hoist-putdown (hoist puts crate onto surface, fuel-cost +1), hoist-load (hoist puts crate into truck respecting capacity numeric guard, fuel-cost +1), hoist-unload (hoist takes crate out of truck and starts lifting, fuel-cost +1). Ensure preconditions and effects capture at/in/on/clear/available/lifting and numeric updates. Objective: minimize fuel-cost. Do not make assumptions beyond the given information. There is no need for anything else beyond producing the pddl files.
